title: Trainspotting
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: Then, when ah wis apprenticed as a chippy wi a Gorgie builder, ah goes along tae Telford College tae dae ma national certificate modules in joinery. Ah sat doon tae ma chips in the cafeteria, whin whae comes along but that cunt Begbie, wi a couple ay other psychos.

title: Tweed and Don; or, Recollections and reflections of an angler for the last fifty years ...
author: Locke, James.
snippet: bridge at the tail-stream of Dairy Mills ; and many a good trout with set lines have I pulled out in the morning, in the garden on the other side. But now the lime which is used at the mills of Gorgie and other places, with the smallness  of its waters from drainage and other causes, make sport at an end here. There is no such thing as a trout to be had, and little done even at Currie and Colinton.

title: The Testament of Gideon Mack
author: Robertson, James
snippet: ﬃce in Victoria Street, with John and Elsie as our witnesses, andafterwards we went to Spain for a week. When we came back, werented a one-bedroom flat in Gorgie and there we lived for the nextthree years, frugally but, I suppose, more or less contentedly.

title: Skagboys
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: Fuck knows what aw this Gorgie stuff was aboot, ah was a Leith boy,but que sera. — By rep only.

title: Skagboys
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: 29wee comment aboot 'Gorgie fashion'. Predictably Keezbo wants tae stopfir chips, when we're barely ootside Edinburgh.

title: Ghost Moon
author: Butlin, Ron
snippet: Her days were an endless round of employment agencies, receptionists, application forms, waiting rooms, interviews. Queuing to use public phones, walking to offices in the New Town, taking trams to offices in Newington, in Leith, in Gorgie, Stockbridge. Come late afternoon she'd usually had enough rejections for the day and would take the next tram she saw going in the direction of Carluke Avenue, to be in time to give Tom his early evening feed.

title: Story of a Stolen Heir. A novel
author: Bertram, James Glass.
snippet: If the reader take the trouble to turnback to chapter third of Book I. of ourstory, he wiU find that the unfortunateClara Douglas, the victim of Lord Bruntsfield, having taken refuge in the humblecottage of a washerwoman, named MysieSemple, at Slockendrouth, near Gorgie,

title: The Right Stuff: Some Episodes in the Career of a North Briton
author: Hay, Ian
snippet: Itwas upon one of these majestic vehicles, which moved down the streetunassisted by any apparent human or equine agency, that he had beenbidden to ride to his destination. He was not to take the first thatcame along, nor yet the second--they went to various places, it seemed;and if you were taken to the wrong one you had to pay just the same--butwas to scan them until he espied one marked "Gorgie." This would carryhim down the Dalry Road, and would ultimately pass the residence ofElspeth M'Kerrow, a decent widow woman, whose late husband's brother had"married on" a connection of Robert's mother.

title: The Right Stuff: Some Episodes in the Career of a North Briton
author: Hay, Ian
snippet: Another blank!Then, "Marchmont Road and Churchill." Foiled again, Robert was beginningto feel a little sceptical as to the actual existence of the Dalry Road,when a car drew up opposite to him labelled "Pilrig and Gorgie." It wasgoing in the right direction too, for his father had warned him that hisdestination lay to the west of the town; and you can trust a Scotsman toknow the points of the compass with his eyes shut.

title: Skagboys
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: Both businesses continued to develop through takeovers and acquisitions, and in 1960, they merged to form Macfarlan Smith Ltd.The companywas taken over by the Glaxo group in 1963. It still employs over twohundred workers at its plant in Wheatfield Road, in the city's Gorgiedistrict.

title: The judge,
author: West, Rebecca
snippet: Ellen stared like a rude child as the woman slowly, with shapeless red fingers, untied her bonnet-strings and revealed herself as something at once agelessly primitive and most modernly  degenerate. The frizzed thicket of coarse hair which broke into a line of tiny, quite circular curls round her low forehead made Ellen remember side-streets round Gorgie and Dairy, which the midday hooters rilled with factory girls horned under their shawls with Hinde's curlers; yet made her remember also vases and friezes in museums where crimped, panoplied priestesses dispensed archaic rites. Her features were so closely moulded to the bone, her temples so protuberant,  and her eyes sunk in such pits of sockets that one had to think of a skull, a skull found in hot sand among ruins.

title: The right stuff,
author: Hay, Ian
snippet: Another blank ! Then, " Marchmont Road and Churchill." Foiled again, Robert was beginning to feel a little sceptical as to the actual existence  of the Dairy Road, when a car drew up opposite to him labelled "Pilrig and Gorgie." It was going in the right direction too, for his father had warned him that his destination lay to the west of the town ; and you can trust a Scotsman to know the points of the compass with his eyes shut.
